nodes.bodyText: We can drop this entirely. If the list of allowed addresses is not empty, we use it. No need for this extra config. Move it to @DefunctConfig on the class.
Let's make this cassandra.load-policy.allowed-addresses and name the field allowedAddresses
How about inclusive. Then we don't need the "aka" in the comment above (which kind of indicates the field should be named better to be self-descriptive)
Remove this along with removing the boolean property

-``cassandra.load-policy.use-white-list``                      Set to ``true`` to use ``WhiteListPolicy``, defaults to ``false``.
+``cassandra.load-policy.use-allow-list``                      Set to ``true`` to use ``AllowListPolicy``, defaults to ``false``.

nodes.bodyText:
The WhiteListPolicy is actually referring to the com.datastax.driver.core.policies.WhiteListPolicy class in the Cassandra driver. We can change the text to

Comma-separated list of hosts to allow.

nodes.bodyText:
We can simplify the entire item (and make it more correct since there other types of plugins)

Prevent plugis from seeing classes that are not part of the JDK (bootstrap classes) or the SPI.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -151,7 +151,7 @@ SPI Changes
 * Make ``NodeManager`` specific to a connector instance.
 * Replace ``ConnectorFactoryContext`` with ``ConnectorContext``.
 * Use ``@SqlNullable`` for functions instead of ``@Nullable``.
-* Use a whitelist model for plugin class loading. This prevents connectors
+* Use an allow-list model for plugin class loading. This prevents connectors

@@ -151,7 +151,7 @@ SPI Changes

nodes.bodyText: // query has too many rows. Consider banning it.
// If we have allowed queries, only run the tests on those
Names of queries that are banned
Names of queries which are allowed. If non-empty, only allowed queries are used.

Let's remove this comment, as we are stuck on an old version of the driver for various reasons. If they deprecate this class name in the 3.x branch, we'd update the usage just like any other deprecated API migration.

This needs to be named getAllowedQueries so that it matches the setter, as config classes use JavaBean conventions and thus require matching names. It causes a test failure:
No getter for @Config method [public io.prestosql.verifier.VerifierConfig io.prestosql.verifier.VerifierConfig.setAllowedQueries(java.lang.String)].
This is no longer used, so we can remove it (along with the getter/setter)

Since we're getting rid of cassandra.load-policy.use-white-list, anyone using this feature will need to update their configs, so we can move this to @DefunctConfig as well (no need to retain it as legacy).

Let's call this allowed-queries
Make sure to update TestVerifierConfig to match
